newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: FORECAST - Ukraine '96 inflation seen at 36 pct.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Ukraine '96 inflation seen at 36 pct.

text.p: Ukraine's inflation rate is slated to fall to about 36 percent this year, down from 182 percent in 1995, and below the government's own forecasts, central bank chief Viktor Yushchenko said on Thursday.
Yushchenko told a news conference in Vienna that accumulative quarterly inflation was expected to drop to six percent in the fourth quarter, from 25 percent in the first three months.

"We have lived up to our commitments," Yushchenko said during an investment conference organised by Creditanstalt bank in Vienna. "Our (anti-inflation) policy will decrease output by two percent. Output dropped 21 percent two years ago, so that is a huge success."

The government has said it expects inflation to fall to about 48 percent this year, and to 25 percent in 1997. The government's economic plan, presented last month, forecasts economic growth of about 1.7 percent next year.

That would be the first economic growth since the country gained independence five years ago. A deep recession has cut Ukraine's gross domestic product to about $35 billion last year, barely 45 percent of its 1990 level. -- Knut Engelmann, Vienna newsroom +431 53112 274
